results.title: Where there's a will...
results.creator_credit: Cine-Service and Victorian Society for Crippled Children and Adults
results.brief_description: The work of the Victorian Society for Crippled Children and Adults in helping the physically handicapped to learn full, happy and as far as possible, independent lives. The Society tries to reach handicapped children early, so that they may benefit from training and companionship in special play centres. Special schools and holiday camps are organised for older children, while Deva Hostel and its annexe provide a home for handicapped young adults from the country, enabling them to further their education and compete for employment. More severely handicapped people are able to work at the Society’s Craft Centre at Albert Park.

results.title: Where have all the farms gone?
results.creator_credit: Michael Brun, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Tumbledown, weatherbeaten old barns and dwellings stand like gaunt skeletons of other times, reproachful of an economy that let them down. Unable to compete with food-chain marketing, the farmers have moved into town, and eventually the bulldozer applies the final indignity to buildings that once represented a full and wholesome way of life. Filmed in 1969 in the Upper Ottawa Valley of Ontario and Quebec, this film carries nostalgia in its mute question: What price progress?

results.title: Where have all the drivers gone?
results.creator_credit: Eric L. Morris and Tarrif Insurance Companies
results.brief_description: A road safety film which stresses that most accidents are caused by careless and inattentive drivers, or by mixing drinking with driving. Graphic scenes of the resulting tragedies - maiming or death - should convince drivers to concentrate on driving or they may discover that the answer to “Where have all the drivers gone?” is “Gone to graveyards every one”! Narrated by Jim Berinson.

results.title: What teacher expects...the self fulfilling prophecy (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, Cristin Weingartner, Dorothy Courtois, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film presenting a provocative theory of interest to educators and parents: that a child’s performance in school is often closely related to what his teacher expects of him, rather than what an intelligence test might indicate him capable of. Dr. Robert Rosenthal of Harvard University and Dr. Sam Rabinovitch of McGill University and the Montreal Children’s Hospital discuss this little-recognised inter-reaction. This theory is demonstrated in teacher-pupil situations where the subject is word-recognition.

results.title: What some communities are doing
results.creator_credit: Joanne M Mock and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Drugs: the children are choosing”.
The sixth film in the series describes two broadly based educational efforts to deal with the problem of youthful drug abuse: (1) designed by a school district; and (2) a community effort by some affluent suburbs. Emphasises the need for a total community commitment and planning.

results.title: What is life?
results.creator_credit: Joseph Koenig, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: What is it that distinguishes the living organism from the non-living, the particular quality common to all living forms? This animated film provides lucid explanation, arresting in colour and form as the facts are presented. It shows what biophysics and biochemistry now perceive as the facts of life concerning evolution and the genetically determining factor of the DNA molecule.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joseph Koenig, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: What goes into the blast furnace?
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description: The manner in which the raw materials used in a blast furnace - iron ore, coke and limestone - are crushed, blended and otherwise prepared before use in a furnace. Animated diagrams explain the use of a continuous hot air blast.

results.title: What are we doing to our children, locked up, locked out
results.brief_description: A poignant case history of a damaged, unstable family and a child’s resultant antisocial behavioral problems. Issues arising from this case are child advocacy in the courts and the rehabilitative effect of jailing juvenile delinquents. From the series CBS reports.

results.title: Wet earth and warm people (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Candid glimpses of Indonesia and its people, in and around the capital, Jakarta. Following where chance leads, the film captures the flavour of life in this fertile crescent of tropical islands as it focuses on the Indonesian people caught between the past and the conflicting options of the future - to change or not to change from long-established patterns of life to ones more influenced by western technology. Awards: Melbourne, Atlanta, San Francisco and Toronto.

results.title: Westminster Abbey
results.brief_description: The history of Westminster Abbey is the history of England. Here Parliament once met; here for centuries the Kings and Queens of England have been crowned; and here are buried illustrious Englishmen of all times - sovereigns, statesmen, poets, scientists, musicians. In the nave is the tomb of an Unknown Warrior, brought from Flanders in 1920 as representative of all the nameless British dead in the War of 1914-18. Westminster Abbey is a fine example of early English architecture. Concludes with scenes of the coronation of King George VIth. The film is accompanied by the Westminster Choir and the London Symphony Orchestra with original music composed and conducted by Horace Shepherd. Commentator: Alvar Lidell.
